comments.value: Put together a proposal for redesigning all the forms on the site to conform with AbilityNet review.
Set to "High" priority, as discussed this morning.
Set to "High" priority, as discussed this morning.
Jamie, a nice chunky bit of work. Requires a short spec. Have you got time this week?

This should be included in the ODA invoice under "response to usability/accessibility review". If this work is less than 5 days, we should carry the days over into other tickets with "AbilityNet review: " in the subject line.

Needs assigning to someone, Janos?

It's multi-part:

- Identify all existing forms
- Collate the collective elements
- Devise a new set of design to cover all elements
- Create new CSS for these elements
- Create new HTML for these elements
- Implemented on all (or a subset to start with) of existing forms.
- * we may be able to fix bu just tweaking the forms and tidying up a new CSS file but this seems unlikely?

Gotchas include: Community tags and CMS data form tags. In that we may need to follow the formate we already have and code CSS to fit.

There are the following forms on the site:
- photo rating
- change password
- choose password
- reset password
- login
- register
- photo search
- contact form
- publication search
- map postcode search
- share page
- banner download

looking at abnet docs for the requirements.

for reference, relevant part of the abilitynet review

* Issues
Form checkboxes are missing <label> tags, as illustrated in Fig 2 
Fig 2 indicating where form labels are not present

 

* Recommendations
All input boxes and other form controls need to be explicitly associated with their labels using the label (tag) element.
Additionally it is necessary to ensure that labels of all form controls are properly placed.
The value of the "for" attribute must be the same as the value of the "id" attribute for the label attribute to work properly. 



* Forms best practice
All form fields should have a text label, with corresponding for and id attributes. Each id has to be unique to the page.
If the text label cannot be fitted into the design, it can be hid using CSS.
If it is not possible to include a label, use a title attribute in the form field explaining the required information.
When there are several associated form elements, they can be grouped together by a fieldset. Each fieldset should have a legend. A screen reader will read out the legend before each form field within it
Important information should be included in label or legend tag.
When using textboxes and select fields, labels should be positioned to the left of the form field
When using checkboxes and radio buttons, labels should be positioned to the right of the form field
Matching the abilitynet requirements shouldn't take more than 1/2-1 hour/page (~15 of them).

1. Photo rating form is now more accessible. To reproduce, disable javascript - it'll fall back to forms and still one will be able to vote. Nb all photo pages are to be republished before this takes effect. http://www.london2012.com/photos/2008/04/thornton-s-field-railway-sidings-53316.php

2. Photo/video search boxes (4 of them) fixed. There were only minor annoyances, few labels missing here and there.

Sorry about the number of comments here, ignore until the story is open.
3. Photo download, banner download pages: already in good shape, no changes required.

awesome. so we're saying 2 days work here? goes in the bill to ODA, so i think we should be fine.

and you've already done the photo pages...is that 1 of 15? or more? slightly confused

 _____

I will ignore unless someone starts is, "Liz-". :-)

 _____

Janos is on leave for a while, so this might remain in an open state until after Easter, but--yes--I believe we can keep this under the 5 days for "AbilityNet" tickets already allocated to the ODA (more or less).
Liz, it's ~fifteen forms altogether, but they're very good at hiding. I'll continue to post as I'm fixing them so that we don't lose too many of them.
4. map postcode search was already accessible. Nb an unrelated (flash?) bug came up w/ map: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/793
5. share page - a few labels were missing, fixed now.
6. publication search - there was one minor bug with a label.

7. Aaand finally registration+account forms. Couple of typos with the labels here and there, nothing serious though.

As previously said, I haven't changed the behavior or design of the forms, just fixed the accessibility bugs. (As a result of this, almost every change here is already published)

We may as well need a story to improve the whole user experience of the registration form based on that funnel testing we may want to do with it :).
This work is now completed, pending approval.
Marking as solved

Hi Liz,

They never lined up (see attached screen shot of original CogApp designs) but now we have moved them around it's more pronounced?

Not sure what the solution is? 

1) Make the ticket promo shallower?

This is probably the most sensible as the other three already all line up 

2) Move the Countdown up a bit

The way the CSS and page is laid out this isn't possible (without significant work / redesigning the page layout)

3) Extend the box / 'Read more news' link down so it lines up with the bottom of ticket promo and add a "see more webcams/videos" link to the bottom of the videos/webcams.  

btw. this is *much* more problematic than it seems, it's not simply a case of adding an "align: bottom property" to those boxes. It's one of those CSS things that always seems easy but is actually tricky to get right cross browser. We'd also need to change/extend the image and alter the CSS for the Map promo (which is used elsewhere).

(1) we could do fairly painlessly (I think that component may be shared, so the height woudl be reduced on all pages that use that promo) but (2) is one of those things we could really waste a lot of time getting right cross browser, we can go down that route but just wanted to clarify it's not as trivial as it seams (we could spend a morning sorting it out / deploying it)

Jamie

We are now in transition to the Windows7 / IE8 platform. While the New Media team plus Debs will still have the option of using Firefox on alternative machines, many of our users will only have IE8. - When user first logged in to CMS through IE8 it flipped her out

- User was working in blog and would not allow her to make a new author to start with. Then user couldn't upload an author photo.

- User was also unable to paste text from notepad into the blog.

Can you please investigate these? Many thanks

This sounds more complicated than I had thought.
There are few classes of a hrefs.
1. Hard coded in templates.
2. Rich text containers.
3. Hyperlink containers.
4. Generated code (e.g. links copied from other pages, etc.)

Also, are there likely to be rules for some fragments, and not for others?
E.g. "Add the image for body text, but not in any <h1> elements", or something like that?
Or "Display a different logo depending on the background color"?

Or am I overcomplicating this Jamie?

No I think it's probably a complex bit of work, which we may be able 
to break down into separate areas, but yes certainly not a trivial 
change that can be covered in a single ticket and one with possible 
unforeseen consequences (at least in some cases)

[This ticket was really to investigate the feasibility of 4. below 
Rich text containers ]

1) Hard coded text links in templates / components

We'd first need to identify all these, agree what to do in each case 
and then change them in templates / components.

2) Automatic Nav bars

I have already broken out the 'related link' nav bar as a separate 
ticket http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/665 that is pretty straight 
forward / self contained.

But yes there are plenty of other query generated nav bars and like 
the hard coded text links they need to be identified and dealt with 
on a case by case basis, some may need bigger or smaller icons, others 
may not want an icon but a pop up label etc.

3) Hyperlinks

Much the same issues and 1 and 2, need to identify them and dealt with 
on a case by case basis

4) Rich text containers

This is the case I was describing in this ticket, the more complex 
case is /any/ rich text container, the simpler case (but not without 
issues) is the main text containers on content pages called 'body'.

--

I was going to suggest to Liz that we could tackle the 'related links' 
nar bar [ http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/665 ] and was going to 
suggest we possibly (depending on complexity / work involved) deal 
with the rich text 'body' container as a starting point.

It sound like a mix of a call back and a container value (or list of) 
may be the solution to dealing with a subset of rich text container 
ie. the body container.

Be good if you could give some thought to the above but I think I 
probably need to discuss this further with Liz as it may not have been 
apparent what the the pit-falls / different cases / technical issues 
here were and therefore need to get agreement on whether it is worth 
us progressing on dealing with a subset of the cases.

Lets leave this ticket for a discussion of the body / rich-text 
container.

If we need to deal with other cases by other means let open separate 
tickets for them, ie. http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/665

thanks

Jamie

That doesn;t realyl help solve the root issue, links in nav bars may not even be stored anywhere (if they are generated automatically), the ones in body text are stored as a blob of XML  the hyperlinks containers are actually stored in the database as link objects. What your asking for is actually at least 4 different pieces of work (the check-box idea would if anything make this even more complex than the simpler case of any link that starts with http:// !) 

I have therefore broken the task down into several tickets, so we can tackle the ones we have easy solutions for and discuss the issues with the other ones separately/as required.

- External links in related sites navigation bar: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/665
- External links inBody text container: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/750 (this ticket)
- External links in other rich text containers: open ticket as/if required
- External links in Hyperlink containers (all or just some?) : open ticket as/if required
- External links hardcoded in templates (need to figure out which links these are) : open ticket as/if required

In terms of links in the 'Body text container' (this ticket) we are working on a solution, which once in place could be rolled out to other containers / templates as required (applying it to any external link in any template/container seems a but rash / likely to result in unwanted issues).

Hope that clarify where we are with this piece/pieces of work/ticket.

Jamie

Liz, can you please have a look at this: http://l.tjp.hu/external.html (it's a copy of a l2012 page w/ external links)
Here's what the script does:

 - searches for all the links in the #MainContent area of the page AND all the links with the classname of "link-external"
 - if they're external (ie don't link to http://london2012.com/ or http://www.london2012.com/)
 - a little external-link icon appears on the left
 - and the link opens in a new window
 - and the hover title changes to / gets amended by 'External link opens in a new window'

As earlier mentioned, it may involve a bit of adjusting to apply this behavior to external links in other areas than the main content - probably it's wise to roll it out first for the main content and see how it works. As it gets approved, it's relatively straightforward to put it live.

I believe I am correct in saying that pictures added to picture boxes are not cropped, but are just resized, maintaining the aspect ratio of the original. 

In this case, the picture has a lot of white space around it (i.e. it's 700 x 700 px), which may have been a mistake. The best way to handle this may be to crop the picture before importing it.

I should qualify my previous comment: some picture boxes are set to crop and others aren't. I don't believe the box in the news article template is, but even if I am wrong, the amount of white space around the image would almost certainly not give you the desired result.
Another addendum: on the other hand, a crop might work OK. We are looking at it now, although  we see that you have done a manual crop for now.

Liz,

There is currently no auto cropping on that image, it looks like the 
vast number of them have been done by hand? *

But no the one you just tried...

Do you want me to add cropping at 460x250? [this will mean any images 
manually uploaded over 250px deep will get cropped the next time their 
page is edited]

Jamie

case, due to where the image live (the resized one get a different path)

comments.value: I am trying to update some pages in IE8 but the Did you know? boxes are not displaying in a manner I can edit. See grab attached.

I believe this may be more general than ie8, IE7 seems to be affected as well.

To work around, click to the preview (eye) button to turn on preview mode, and then again to turn it off. This will fix the rendering issue.

Feel free not to close this as we'll need to find a proper fix.
is this fixed with the IE8 code deployment?  what's the scoop?
michael is back & test machines are happier than ever - will take a proper look today.
Morag, Liz, can anyone confirm if it's an IE8 issue? Looking at it at the moment and seems to be OK on ie8 (unless in compatibility mode). IE7 has this issue, and we're still looking at it.
As I believe you are no longer going to be using IE7 and we have not been able to reproduce on IE8, I am marking this as solved.

subject: IE bug with Did you know?
description: I am trying to update some pages in IE8 but the Did you know? boxes are not displaying in a manner I can edit. See grab attached.

comments.value: I have flaggedt this already but just to formalise the requirement: as of the end of March LOCOG will be moving to IE8. We therefore need to ensure there is compatability with the CMS. I am currently already on IE8 and have noticed a few issues e.g. exporting user reports doesn't work in IE8.
Marked to high. reminder: Switch over to IE8 before March 31st.

I am already on IE8 and am finding quite a lot of issues with the CMS.
Do you want me to start posting them here?

 

________________________________
Morag, please do.
Morag, it would be very helpful if you could raise a separate ticket for each issue you find.
I am doing so. Can you let me know how the IE8 testing / upgrade is coming on?

I can confirm that the following IE8 issue is solved pending a code deployment:
http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/655

Please do keep sending us your IE8 issues.

Also, it would be useful to get an update on when you are due to change from IE7 to IE8.
Marking as solved
